comments:
Using 0917, I ended up with a empty tree. See attached screenshot.
I had to close the variable view and reopen it to fix it.
The only thing I had in my .log file was that a widget is disposed.

This happened just after the following error:

The VM I am using is:
java version "1.4.1_02"
Java(TM) 2 Runtime Environment, Standard Edition (build 1.4.1_02-b06)
Java HotSpot(TM) Client VM (build 1.4.1_02-b06, mixed mode)
I used this VM for a while and I got this error repeatedly since I0910.
Same issue with JDK1.4.2_01. I will investigate without the JIT.
*** Bug 42970 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

NOTE: Just to confirm - you need to change the VM Eclipse is running on, not 
the VM your debugged application is running on.

Just FYI, this happened several times to me as well. This seems to happen when 
stepping quickly (e.g. pressing F6 repeatidly)

Just wanted to add that I'm getting the same behaviour repeatedly.  I doesn't
always happen in the same place, but it always happens during stepping (F5 or F6).

My VM: Sun build 1.4.1_01-b01

I agree from looking at the code that the stack trace appears to be
impossible... possibly it's a JIT bug?  For safety you could always use
String.valueOf(fValue) instead of fValue.toString() (or make fValue field final).

It seems I actually have to restart Eclipse once I get into this state. 
Restarting the debug session does not fix the corrupt variables view. It seems
the easiest way to reproduce is to hold down F6 to repeatedly step while a
variable is selected in the variables view.

I have not been able to reproduce this problem yet (I have tried on 1.4.1 and 
1.4.2 VMs). It looks like a VM bug. I will try the suggested fix (i.e. valueOf
(..)).
made fix and released to map for tomorrow's re-build.
*** Bug 44537 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
*** Bug 44982 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
